review.title: Improving a Strong Neural Parser with Conjunction-Specific Features
review.abstract: While dependency parsers reach very high overall accuracy, some dependency relations are much harder than others. In particular, dependency parsers perform poorly in coordination construction (i.e., correctly attaching the "conj" relation). We extend a state-of-the-art dependency parser with conjunction-specific features, focusing on the similarity between the conjuncts head words. Training the extended parser yields an improvement in "conj" attachment as well as in overall dependency parsing accuracy on the Stanford dependency conversion of the Penn TreeBank.

metadata.title: Improving a Strong Neural Parser with Conjunction-Specific Features

sections.text: While dependency savers achieve a very high overall accuracy, some dependency relationships are much more difficult than others. In particular, dependency savers perform poorly in coordination construction (i.e., properly appending the conj relationship). We extend a state-of-the-art dependency parser to include conjuncture-specific traits, focusing on similarity between conjunct headers. Training the advanced parser improves the conj binding and the overall accuracy of the dependency savers in the Stanford conversion of Penn TreeBank.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In the appendices predicted by BIST parsers (Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016), the F1 score for the labels nn, nsubj, pobj, and others is still persistently wrong when it comes to establishing specific relationships; while the formula 1 scores for Advent, conj, and prep are 83.3%, 82.5%, and 87.4%. Conjunction holds the lowest formula 1 rating, ignoring rare labels, dep, and punct. Other parsers behave similarly. Connecting errors also occur in simple sentences, such as: (1) "These machines are still considered novelties, with keyboards that have only one match." (2)

sections.heading: 2 Symmetry between Conjuncts
sections.text: It is known that conjunctions are semantically related and often have a similar syntactical structure. This property of coordination was used in earlier work to disambiguate coordination as a guiding principle (Hara et al., 2009; Hogan, 2007; Shimbo and Hara, 2007; Ficler and Goldberg, 2016). While these focus on symmetries between conjunctions in constituency structures, we use the symmetrical annunciation for the purpose of improving dependency analysis. sections.heading: 3 Conjunction Features
sections.text: We propose a series of characteristics specifically designed for the conjunctive relationship, targeting the symmetry aspect of headwords. Characteristics are summarized in Table 2 and are detailed below: CAP - The case where both conjunctions start with a capital letter is much more common (> 3 x) than the case where only one of the headwords begins with a capital letter. These cases are usually names of people, countries and organizations; and generic phrases such as "Mac and Cheese." This characteristic is rare in other labels except nn. We capture this characteristic with a Boolean characteristic that indicates whether both conjunctive headwords begin with a capital letter. SUF - In some of the conjunctions, headwords take a similar form to those in (codification, geographical), we are.

sections.heading: 4 Incorporating conjunction features
sections.text: This parser is a greedy, transition-based parser that uses the archybrid transition system (Kuhlmann et al., 2011). At each step of the parsing process, the parser selects one of two possible transitions: SHIFT, RIGHT (rel), and LEFT (rel). The left and right transitions add a dependency edge to the label rel. At each step, all transitions are evaluated, and the transition with the highest score is applied. Stanford's dependency scheme specifies that the Konj relation appears as a right edge and can therefore only be generated by a RIGHT (conj) transition. We calculate a score sconj that is added to the score of the RIGHT (conj) transition generated by the parser. Sconj is calculated by an MP transition that gets a specific function that forms the MV characteristics and the associated LP parser.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We show that a linguistically motivated and data-driven feature set for a particular syntactic relationship (coordinating conjunction) improves strong baseline analysis, and the features we propose explicitly model symmetry between headers in coordination constructions. Although we demonstrated their effectiveness in a greedy transition-based parser, the information our features capture is not currently captured by other dependency analysis architectures (including top-notch graph-based parsers, higher-level graph-based parsers, beam-based transition parsers), and these features will be easy to integrate into such parsers, and we expect them to be effective for them, too.
